solution.text:
Step One
  • Leave equation A untouched.
  • Flip equation B, because we need \(CS_2\) as a reactant.
  • Multiply equation C by a factor of 2, because we want \(2SO_2\) as a product.
Step Two - Revised Equations
  • \(C(s) + O_2(g) \rightarrow CO_2(g) \qquad \Delta H = -_{j}_ \frac{kJ}{mol}\)
  • \(CS_2(l) \rightarrow C(s) + 2S(s) \qquad \Delta H = - _{l}_ \frac{kJ}{mol}\)
  • \(2S(s) + 2O_2(g) \rightarrow 2SO_2(g) \qquad \Delta H = - _{{2*k}}_ \frac{kJ}{mol}\)
Step Three : Add the revised equations to get the desired one
\(C(s) + O_2(g) + CS_2(l) + 2S(s) + 2O_2(g) \rightarrow CO_2(g) + C(s) + 2S(s) + 2SO_2(g)\)
\(\implies CS_2(l) + 3O_2(g) \rightarrow CO_2(g) + 2SO_2(g)\)

Step Four : Add the revised enthalpies
\(\implies \Delta H = -_{j}_ - _{l}_ - _{{2*k}}_ = - _{{j+l+(2*k)}}_\frac{kJ}{mol}\)

content.text:
Calculate the enthalpy of change for the reaction below that is conducted at a certain temperature and pressure:
\(CS_2(l) + 3O_2(g) \rightarrow CO_2(g) + 2SO_2(g)\)

Given that the following reactions are conducted under the same conditions:\(C(s) + O_2(g) \rightarrow CO_2(g) \qquad \Delta H = -_{j}_ \frac{kJ}{mol} \qquad (A)\)
\(C(s) + 2S(s) \rightarrow CS_2(l) \qquad \Delta H = _{l}_ \frac{kJ}{mol} \qquad (B)\)
\(S(s) + O_2(g) \rightarrow SO_2(g) \qquad \Delta H = - _{k}_ \frac{kJ}{mol} \qquad (C)\)
